content: How can I help you today?

I’m not really sure, honestly. My wife wanted me to come here, but I’m skeptical about all of this. Things at home have been really tough, especially with my son, and I’ve been feeling pretty overwhelmed. I guess I’m here because I just don’t know what else to do.

Thanks for sharing that—it sounds like things have been really challenging for you lately. You're feeling overwhelmed at home, and even though you're unsure about being here, you're open to exploring what might help. That shows courage. What’s been going on with your son that’s been adding to the overwhelm?

My son has been acting out a lot—tantrums, not listening, getting in trouble at school. My wife and I are both at our wits' end trying to figure out how to help him. It’s causing a lot of tension between us, and I feel like we’re arguing all the time. I just don’t know how to fix it.

You’ve been trying really hard to help your son and support your family, but the behavior challenges and added stress at home are taking a toll on you and your relationship with your wife. It sounds like you care deeply and want things to improve—for everyone. What do you think has made this situation feel so overwhelming for you?

I think it's just everything piling up at once. It’s not just my son’s behavior—but the constant tension, the fights with my wife, feeling like I don’t know what to do to make things better. And on top of that, I feel like I’m failing my daughter because I don’t spend as much time with her. All of it just makes me feel stuck.

You’re carrying a lot right now—feeling stuck, stretched thin, and unsure how to handle everything coming at you. You care so much about your family and want to support everyone, but it’s hard when you feel pulled in so many directions. What do you think might help you feel just a little less stuck?

I honestly don’t know. It feels like everything’s so overwhelming that I don’t even know where to start. Maybe just figuring out how to handle one thing at a time would help, but I’m not sure where to even begin.

It feels like taking small steps and focusing on one thing at a time might give you a sense of direction, but right now it’s hard to even decide where to begin. That’s understandable—it’s tough to find clarity when things feel overwhelming. If you could imagine one thing improving, whether at home or within yourself, what would that look like for you?

I guess if I could imagine one thing improving, it would be feeling more connected as a family again. If we could stop all the fighting, help my son feel better, and have time for my daughter too, that would mean everything. I just don’t know how to get us there.

It sounds like reconnecting as a family is really important to you—you want a calmer, more supportive environment where everyone feels cared for, including your son and daughter. That hope for improvement says a lot about your dedication to your family. What would reconnecting as a family mean for you personally? How might it affect how you’re feeling inside?

If we could reconnect, I think I’d feel less like a failure and more like I’m doing something right as a parent and a husband. Right now, I feel like I’m letting everyone down, and it’s hard to shake that. If we could get to a better place as a family, I think I’d finally feel some relief.

Reconnecting as a family feels like it would ease that heavy weight of self-doubt you're carrying. You want to feel like you're succeeding in supporting your loved ones, and that relief would mean so much to you. What do you think might be getting in the way of finding that better place for your family?

I think it’s partly the constant stress and not knowing how to help my son. My wife and I are both so overwhelmed, and it feels like we’re blaming each other instead of working together. We’re stuck in this cycle, and I don’t know how to break it.

The stress and uncertainty about how to support your son have fueled a cycle that’s straining your connection with your wife. It sounds like breaking that cycle—finding ways to work together and not feel stuck—could be a key step toward easing the tension and moving forward. What would it take to start shifting that dynamic and working together more as a team?

I think it would take us being able to communicate without getting defensive or frustrated with each other. Right now, it feels like we’re just running on empty, and everything turns into a fight. Maybe if we could actually sit down and figure out a plan together, it might help, but I don’t know where to start with that.

Opening up communication with less defensiveness and frustration would create space for collaboration and problem-solving as a team. Even the idea of sitting down together to create a plan seems like a meaningful step, but figuring out where to start can feel challenging when things are overwhelming. Is there something small—something manageable—you think you both could focus on first that might open the door to better teamwork?

Maybe we could start with setting aside some time to talk without interruptions—just the two of us—so we could focus on what’s not working and what we need from each other. It feels like so much has built up that we haven’t really had a calm conversation about it in a long time. I think just starting there might help.

Setting aside uninterrupted time to talk calmly and openly could be a powerful first step toward breaking the cycle and understanding each other better. It sounds like being able to speak without distractions or heightened emotions might help you both reconnect and start focusing on solutions together. Is there anything else you'd like to explore or reflect on before moving forward with this idea?

Setting aside that time to talk sounds like a really constructive starting point. Being able to communicate calmly could help you both understand each other’s perspective and work as a team again. What can you do to make sure that this conversation feels safe and productive for both of you?

It could mean making some agreements ahead of time—like approaching the conversation with patience, avoiding blame, and focusing on shared goals. Maybe creating a quiet space where you both feel comfortable could help too. What do you think would help you and your wife feel supported and open during that time?
